---
layout: post
title:      "What is the Central Limit Theorem and Why Should I Care?"
date:       2020-07-12 01:52:39 +0000
permalink:  what_is_the_central_limit_theorem_and_why_should_i_care
---

It is sometimes said that you don’t truly understand a concept until you can teach it to someone else. Today, I’m going to attempt to do that with an important concept in statistics and data science: the Central Limit Theorem (CLT). I’ll admit that the first time (or second time, or third time…) that I heard the CLT mentioned, I really didn’t understand what it meant. So, this post is written as much for me as anyone else, and maybe we will all understand the CLT a little bit better at the end!

#### Definition

The main idea behind the CLT is this: for nearly any statistical distribution, if repeated random sampling is performed on that distribution, the means of those samples will tend to approximate a normal distribution as the number of samples collected grows.

As with most statistical concepts, the CLT can be best explained with examples. Below, I demonstrate the CLT using a couple of simple cases in Python.

#### Example #1: Uniform Distribution

Let's consider a regular six-sided die. The probability of rolling any number, one through six, on a given roll is equal at ⅙ (17%). Since there is an equal probability of rolling any number on the die, this represents an example of a uniform distribution. 

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

Now, let’s try a few experiments. We can collect one sample from this uniform distribution by rolling the die n times. If we then calculate the mean of those n instances, we can call this a sample mean. We can then repeat this process k times, which will give us the distribution of sample means,  which approximate a normal distribution (if k is large enough).

The Python code below will sample our die by performing five die rolls per sample, taking the mean of those five rolls per sample, and repeating this process for ten total samples.

```
# Code to generate k = 10 random samples of size n = 5

# Container to hold the means for each sample
sample_means_10 = []

# Loop to calculate the mean of each random sample from the distribution
for i in range(10):
    sample = np.random.randint(low=1, high=7, size=5)
    sample_means_10.append(sample.mean())
```

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

Based on this histogram, k=10 samples is clearly not enough for the sample means to begin to approximate the normal distribution.

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

Repeating the sampling k=100 times produces something a little closer to a normal distribution.

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

Now we’re getting there! Performing k=1,000 random samples results in something pretty ‘normally-distributed’.

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

Finally, as we increase the number of samples towards infinity (k=10,000 shown), the distribution of sample means will more closely approximate the normal distribution.

#### Example # 2: Binomial Distribution

One example is great, but what if we try this experiment with another type of statistical distribution? 

For the second example, let's consider a  telemarketer making cold calls to sell magazines. Let’s say that the probability of success (making a sale) for any given call is about 5% (5 calls in 100). This is an example of the binomial distribution, as there are only two possible outcomes of the cold call - Success or Failure.

However, as in the first example, if we collect a large number of random samples from this distribution, the distribution of all of the sample mean’ will tend toward a normal distribution with an increasing k number of random samples.

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

As we increase the number of samples by orders of magnitude in the plots above, we can see the CLT beginning to take shape in this second example. At k=10 samples, the sample mean distribution looks definitely non-normal. However, by k=10,000 random samples, we see something that passes as a normal distribution.

#### Why does it matter?

The CLT isn’t just a cool party trick - it is actually foundational to applied statistics. Specifically, the CLT allows us to do things like construct confidence intervals and perform hypothesis testing when we may not know much about the distribution of a population. These applications (confidence intervals, hypothesis testing) require that our data can be modeled as a normal distribution. As we’ve seen above, the CLT allows for this if we can collect enough random samples from the population - even if that population does not follow a normal distribution!
